I was specifically looking for a habit tracker that accommodates weekly, monthly, and "irregular" (say, "three times a week") habits, and Loop fits the bill! The app is very simple but also flexible because you can set intervals exactly how you want to. The interface is not flashy, but it works. (I tried Habitica and loved the gamification - but it wasn't helpful for non-daily habits.) I also really appreciate the lack of ads and paywalls - I believe the develop has an ethos of not taking money. I would love to see a space for notes: for my monthly habits, I would like to jot down what cause I donated to in Jan, Feb, etc.; or who I reached out to for interviews. I'm not a data nerd, but the graphs and metrics that the app provides will be appealing to people who are into such things.

This is the most useful app I've ever used and I just cannot sing its praises enough. It took me months to discover this, but if you forget to check something you can click onto the habit, navigate to the calendar, click edit, and tap any dates that you know you did a habit. This helped me enormously. Also, if your habit is one of avoidance, just phrase it as "no coffee" or what have you and check if avoided. That's worked fine for me!

What's going on with the new version permissions? The app description states, "[Loop] works offline and respects your privacy. Loop doesn't require an Internet connection or online account registration. Your confidential data is never sent to anyone." And yet, version 1.8.8 has added new permissions. The app may request the following permissions: NEW have full network access; NEW view network connections. Why does the app need these new permissions? Rating edited. Thank you for your response.
google_play_reviews.replyContent: Hi Daniel, these permissions are for an experimental multi-device sync feature we are currently testing, and which we plan to release in the near future. When available, it will be opt-in. The app does not (and will not) request internet permission unless you enable this feature. You can read more at: github.com/iSoron/uhabits/issues/104
